awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Significance of Cenozoic climate and environmental changes on the ecology and evolution of marsupials in Australia: A multi-proxy approach
awd_abstract_narration:
New Title:
CAREER: Significance of climate and environmental changes on the ecology and evolution of marsupials in Australia: evidence from the analysis of fossil teeth over deep-time

Non-technical abstract:
Assessing how mammals have responded to past climate and environmental change can help clarify how living mammals may respond to current climate change.  As Australia is projected to experience more extreme drought and intense precipitation events and extreme temperature increases by 2050, it is critical to assess the effects of climate change and habitat modification on living and fossil mammals.  Throughout deep-time, landscapes in Australia have change from primarily moist forests to more temperate and drier regions.  Increased aridity likely had profound impacts on the evolution and extinction of marsupial mammals; however, critical work is needed to better understand the ecology of marsupial mammals both today and in the past.  Using an integrative approach that combines data resulting from a diversity of analytical methods, these data can clarify long-term responses to climate change and reveal potential reasons as to why many mammals went extinct.  This research will be integrated with educational activities, including the involvement of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students (including gender and/or ethnic minorities, with involvement of student from the Tennessee School for the Blind).  Through a combination of student research experiences that include conducting primary research and digital outreach products, formal mentoring, and a diversity of educational outreach programs, this CAREER research will be broadly disseminated to both local and global audiences.

Technical abstract:
The primary goal of this CAREER research is to clarify the ecology and biology of marsupial mammals in Australia during the Cenozoic to: (1) assess changes in environmental and climatic conditions, including potential declines in forested environments; and (2) clarify how mammals have responded to climate change, including increased aridity since the Miocene and more pronounced aridification since ~350 thousand years ago.   Through the integration of stable isotope analyses of fossil tooth enamel, 3D dental microwear texture analysis, dental mesowear analysis, and morphological analysis, the paleoecology and paleobiology of numerous herbivorous and carnivorous mammals can be used to test a multitude of hypotheses regarding the evolution and extinction of marsupial mammals in Australia - including clarifying long-term responses to climate change.  The integration of long-term paleontological evidence with modern ecological studies of extant macropodid responses to recent drought events, can synergistically clarify biotic responses to aridification. The research will be integrated with all proposed educational activities, including: 1) conducting primary research projects as part of undergraduate and graduate coursework; 2) mentor high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in both primary research and educational outreach activities; 3) work with the Tennessee School for the Blind to conduct primary mesowear research and engage in educational outreach, 4) encourage females and/or underrepresented minorities to consider STEM careers via participation in both the Girls and Science Camp at Vanderbilt University and TWISTER at the Adventure Science Center, and 5) increase scientific literacy and visibility of research activities and outcomes through the development of docent carts and training at the Nashville Zoo and through public outreach events at local venues.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Australia, being one of the hottest and driest places on the planet also serves as a canary in the coal mine, alerting global citizens to the consequences of climate change and aridification on biotic organisms.  The primary focus of a 5-year NSF CAREER grant was to clarify the ancient ecology and biology of marsupial mammals in Australia during the Cenozoic using interdisciplinary tools and approaches that integrate morphological data with stable isotopes, dental microwear texture analysis, and dental mesowear.  This NSF CAREER grant has resulted in over 40 talks presented at professional scientific conferences across the globe, with a focus on North America and Australia, numerous journal articles, and a diversity of broader impact activities aimed at local, regional, and global audiences (many of which are openly accessible on-line).  CAREER grants have only one PI, who is also underrepresented in regard to gender and disability status in the geosciences; however, the majority of activities have been collaborative with scientific colleagues and trainees, in North America, Australia, and throughout the globe.  Further, research experiences were integrated into Vanderbilt University courses and discoveries were presented in seminar talks given as a Distinguished Speaker for the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology.

 

We have examined marsupial mammals from throughout Australia during the Miocene, Plio-Pleistocene, and today, assessing how dietary niches varied geographically, temporally, and in response to climate change and/or human occupation.  Furthermore, our research extends beyond scientific inquiry to address real-world conservation challenges faced by Australian land managers. By shedding light on the ecology of current animals during the Pleistocene and Holocene, we provide valuable insights that inform conservation efforts.  Since the inception of the project, we have published a total of 19 peer-reviewed papers (3 of these published in Young Scientist by high school students), excluding several forthcoming papers. These publications encompass a broad range of topics related to paleoecology and conservation, including dietary ecology, climate change impacts, and marsupial evolution.  This project has helped train numerous scientists and future professionals in the fields of paleontology, biology, geology, ecology, geochemistry, and anthropology.  These include 8 graduate students, 25+ undergraduate students, 2 high school students, and outreach events that have reaching hundreds to thousands of participants locally and globally.

 

Examples of Broader Impact activities that have reached the general public, include:

Local and Regional Outreach

  • Numerous presentations to local public schools (career days, fourth grade fossil week, and science camps).
  • Collaborations with the Adventure Science Center (Science Cafes, Tennessee Women in Science, Technology, Engineering & Research (TWISTER) STEM Conference for Girls in Grades 9-12)
  • Improve Science Theater 4000 Presents: Prehistoric Predators with Dr. Frizzle. Third Coast Comedy Club.
  • Developed an Arid World docent cart with the Nashville Zoo to help communicate about the ecology and evolutionary history of marsupials in Australia.
  • Virtual presentation to a Nashville area on-line class of elementary school students about paleontology. 
  • International Education Week: Climate Change Research Symposium. Sponsored by the Graduate School, Vanderbilt University.
  • The Pleistocene's Most Notorious Predators: Decoding the Ecology of Ancient Predators and their Prey. Burpee Museum of Natural History, Rockford, IL.
  • Putting STEAM Back into STEM: Challenging Students to Creatively Communicate Scientific Concepts to Public Audiences. National Science Teacher Association.
  • Why diets matter and are key to understanding ancient and modern ecosystems. Nutrition Advisory Group to the Association of Zoos and Aquariums.

 On-line Talks

  • Chewing on Change. Darwin Day On-line Symposium, coordinated and sponsored by the National Center for Science Education. (https://youtu.be/PJjtD94nVI0)
  • Cautionary Conservation Lessons from the Paleontological Record. The Royal Irish Academy Discourse Lecture Series.  In person and virtual (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgloKiGjej8).
  • A Diprotodon in the Coal Mine: Conservation Lessons from Australian Fossils (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nVQ4FElOj6w&feature=emb_logo).
  • Ask a Vanderbilt Paleontologist  (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LLoS5-2WB8). 
  • Elementary School Career Day video developed for schools across the globe. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_7tm33s2u6Q&t=1s
  • TEDx Vanderbilt: Our Ancient Past is the Key to Our Future. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h8x5XtyR99Y)

 Other Media

  • An article about PI DeSantis published by the National Center for Science Education: https://ncse.ngo/larisa-desantis-changing-face-science-one-outreach-experience-time
  • The Wild Life (Podcast), Saving Quokkas Now, Using the Past with Dr. Larisa DeSantis (see: https://www.audible.com/pd/Saving-Quokkas-Now-Using-the-Past-with-Dr-Larisa-DeSantis-Podcast/B08VZR7L8B).
  • Video press releases that accompanied peer-reviewed publications.  Examples include one on megafaunal extinctions at Cuddie Springs (https://youtu.be/222v7T52B3k) and another on deciphering the ecology of animals from their teeth (https://youtu.be/pTEtkIxjRPk)
  • Completion of a book aimed at providing underrepresented role models in STEM fields to children.  The book is titled, I'm a Vertebrate Paleontologist Now! By Larisa DeSantis. To be Published June 11, 2024. World Scientific: https://doi.org/10.1142/13573. 48 pages.
  • Publishing a children's book (in press) Fox Food that discusses the consequence of invasive species to Australian mammals in Western Australia.  Copies of this book are being donated to local communities in Western Australia. 
  • Examples of articles about grant related research: Megafaunal Extinctions (https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/changing-climate-not-humans-killed-australias-massive-mammals-180961911/); quokka declines (https://www.upi.com/Science_News/2020/02/24/Study-details-decline-of-Australias-quokkas/5521582560037/); quokka research (https://www.discovermagazine.com/planet-earth/meet-the-adorable-quokka-known-as-the-happiest-animal-on-earth); marsupial lion extinctions (https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-07128-z); and marsupial teeth (https://everyone.plos.org/2018/09/04/mesowear-of-marsupial-teeth/)
  • See also: www.DeSantisLab.com

 


Last Modified: 05/14/2024
Modified by: Larisa Grawe Desantis
